messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:53): zcorpan: thanks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: is it by any chance possible that JAWS might be a piece of software with bad defaults but configurable to be more bearable?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:54): I hear it has lots of prefs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:54): it certainly has bad defaults
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:55): but the prefs UI is amongst the worst UI i have ever seen (or heard)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:55): it's worse than the windows registry
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:57): gets out the JAWS manual to work out how the heck to navigate the Web again
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:01): god jaws sucks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:01): i'm at the windows desktop
67ab482559bf3f830bdf948ab892778a (02:01): wonders if hixie used jaws with a piece of cloth on his eyes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:01): i turn the screen off
67ab482559bf3f830bdf948ab892778a (02:01): ah good, but I would have shut off my visual sense
67ab482559bf3f830bdf948ab892778a (02:02): it is an interesting experiment
67ab482559bf3f830bdf948ab892778a (02:02): though desktop browsers from what I see from my parents are also very hard to use
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:02): i can't close my eyes, with my eyes closed i couldn't read the jaws manual which i need to work out wtf the navigation keys are
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:03): finally finds "read line" in the manual (Caps Lock + I, obviously)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:03): It's all right, it's all right 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, she moves in mysterious ways.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:03): woot, finally launched IE
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:04): (yes, I'm getting my own back on all your hidden references to various things)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:05): heh
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:06): it's not really hard to find, though
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:06): anyhow, school starts in just under nine hours, time for me to go sleep

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:09): on this page:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:09): http://www.hixie.ch/tests/adhoc/html/screen-readers/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:10): it says "Index of /tests/adhoc/html/screen-readers" three times
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:10): and says "eighty" twice (at the end of a line each time)
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:10): it should say the first thing twice because it is in both title and h1
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:11): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I have no idea.  I'm getting a windows mobile smartphone tomorrow, though, so I guess I'll see how well it works then...
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:11): I guess I can get opera mobile or whatever the portable mozilla browser's called though
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:11): http://www.lukew.com/resources/articles/PSactions.asp
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): 0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8: twice i would understand
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: 80?  is that the width of the line or something?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): (though it's still retarded)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: maybe? but why does it say it, even then?!
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:13): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: What happens in Fox?
67ab482559bf3f830bdf948ab892778a (02:13): nah it is not 80, but "s'ti" in Quebecois. It means something like "geez"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:14): 0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8: dunno, don't want to go through the pain of switching browsers yet!
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:14): I think part of the problem of screenreaders for the web is that there isn't actually a web-specific screnreader
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:14): one of those could do a much better job, I imagine
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:15): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: There are. But there shouldn't be any need for such a thing.
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:15): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: HTML is in a lot of different applications, don't forget, not just web browsers.
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:15): e.g. WebKit is used in Colloquy and Mail
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:16): mm, true.  but in applications it tends to be slightly different, since they're not browsers
67ab482559bf3f830bdf948ab892778a (02:16): plus the fact that navigating the web is not the only thing
67ab482559bf3f830bdf948ab892778a (02:16): you have to be able to use the desktop as large
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:16): and the process of transmuting HTML to a screen reader-navigable DOM is very similar to that for Word files and PDF files and everything

0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:17): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: There have been many attempts at providing dedicated browsers. But there are major advantages to using the same software as sighted peers.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:17): i tend to agree that there should be a dedicated speech browser rather than a screen reader, but that's a separate problem entirely
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:17): fair enough.  I can see that
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (02:18): but if HTML5 works out, then I would imagine that a dedicated browser would be much easier than at present
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): sure wish i knew why it kept saying "ninety eight percent"
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: That's page load information.
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:18): i.e. how much of the page has loaded
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:19): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: quite possibly that was your 80 earlier too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:19): no, IE is not doing anything
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:19): maybe, though i doubt it, it happens in the same place on that page

0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:30): I don't think it would
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:30): i hit "say paragraph" and it says "blank"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:30): helpful, thanks jaws
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:30): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: try just tabbing around?
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:30): (if this is a dialog)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:30): 0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8: an alert dialog, i mean
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): 0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8: pressing tab just makes it say "tab".
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): i can't get it to read me the message again
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:31): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: try INSERT + B (read current window)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): wait, i've found the bug
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): (i'm in laptop mode, btw, so i use caps lock instead of insert)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): caps lock Y dismisses the alert dialog without telling me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): christ is that confusing
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:33): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: ah okay.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): caps lock - b is a useful command, thanks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:34): i don't understand why caps lock - a isn't the same thing though
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:34): why two commands?
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:35): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Judging from http://www.freedomscientific.com/fs_products/JAWSkeystrokes.asp INSERT+A just reads the address bar
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): capslock+a is say all in laptop mode
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:36): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I suspect say all is specific to buffers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): seems so
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:36): whereas in dialogs JAWS would be in some sort of mode that more closely follows MSAA
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:36): (like forms mode in webpages)
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (02:38): If you have a window which also has a document loaded into a buffer, I guess there is a logic in there being two different commands.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:40): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:55): ok, here's a test case for JAWS: http://www.hixie.ch/tests/adhoc/html/screen-readers/001.html
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (03:00): What's it reading wrong there?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:01): reads everything after "elephants" on the second line in the same voice as "elephants"
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (03:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: This is with the Web Rent-A-Crowd scheme or something is it?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:02): yeah
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (03:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what happens if you turn on announcements too? does it think there's more than one link there?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:07): hunts for announcements
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (03:08): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: sorry, that's not necessarily the technical term
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (03:09): I just mean where it will say "unvisited link" or whatever before a link
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:10): not sure how to enable that, but it does say "visited link" once on that page
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (03:11): well at least it only thinks there's one link
0c613432f4687d9dae0e13d1af514eb8 (03:11): are you sure you've got the voices different enough that you'd be able to tell the difference?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:11): oh yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:11): one is male and the other female
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:12): i love the way it reads the first line, too:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:14): "In the following text, only one word left paren the word. Quote elephants quote. Right paren! should be said like a link."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:14): though that depends on the synthesiser
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:15): SAPI5 in particular seems to suck.
